narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: 3&4: The workload for this class was just perfect. I enjoyed the readings each week (not too many, usually) and the one-page summary was helpful without being a hassle each week. I think the length and timing of the policy memo worked great; I was able to explore an issue in depth by just focusing on the basics and employing numbers/tables/figures. I appreciated the list of suggested memo topics too.5: I liked that the professor made it clear from the start that this class is discussion-based, and I feel like people felt free to critique and comment, and the professor handled that well. He was usually able to help clarify or provide a contrasting point of view, but was also honest when he didn't know something, which I appreciated. He would always look it up later and fill us in next time.7: the professor is very knowledgeable and was able to clearly articulate not only the main concepts, but also details of processes and patterns. He was really helpful in office hours, and very flexible, which I think everyone appreciated.
I really enjoyed this class. There was a lot of work with commentaries each week, but it made me understand and appreciate the material that much more.
The course was too general with lots of readings, which made it hard to grab concepts. Although the course was introductory, it should focus on a few things to match time.
Readings were sometimes hard to understand, but the lectures were helpful to clarify.

4. The course requires a lot of reading followed up by commentaries. Although it is a lot of work to complete the readings and the commentaries before the next class, I found that these requirements pushed me to read the materials. The class discussions helped develop my understanding of the readings even further.6. We covered a lot of difference concepts in a very short amount of time, so we didn't get to dig as deep as I expected.
The course is a general survey of climate change. It is interesting, but very broad and lacks a cohesive narrative or perspective.
This class was amazing/
Question 10--A course on mixed methods would be really helpful for MESc students who are using both natural and social science research methods.
I only audit the course, so can't comment on some of the questions above.
The broad overview it provided in all aspects of climate change, as well as its multidisciplinary approach and the emphasis on participation.
The broad overview on climate change (science, policy, adaptation, mitigation) without feeling rushed or feeling like we didn't go in depth with anything, because I felt we did.
The lectures were insightful and rich. A lot of material in each one.
The best thing is that all the aspects of climate change, from economics to geoengineering were covered in the class.

This course was able to cover many topics concerning climate change in one semester. It provided a great introduction to vulnerability, adaptation, and mitigation.I specifically liked how the course was broken down into lecture and discussion. The discussion encouraged student participation,which made the class much more engaging.
the lectures

Learning about all the different facets of climate change. I found that topics covered in this class helped me to understand and offer thoughtful insight during my discussions in other classes involving economics, water scarcity and business management.I also thought that the memo assignment offered practical experience that will be useful in my future career.

The one-page reading responses due each week were very helpful to ensure that I analyzed the reading before class. The adaptation memo and final research paper were also excellent assignments to delve deeper into material that was interesting to me.
I loved the readings and I loved the overview of the topics. At the same time anything I was particularly interested in I could explore in incredible depth.
-Class atmosphere-Selection of readings-Quality of discussions
Student Discussions.
The best thing about this course was the readings. The papers selected for the purpose were so informative that I feel ready today to answer any issue pertaining to climate change.
the teaching methods are good. I thought it was very helpful to do commentaries after for the reading sets.

This is probably the best course I've ever taken. The format makes you learn a lot. Readings that you definitely read since you have to post a commentary the day before class. Well presented lectures from the Professor or invited lecturers that condense a lot of knowledge. Well selected sources of information. Great discussion, which are also led by students. And a couple of papers, one of which is actually Memo, very useful. The lectures are uploaded just before class so you can make notes on it during class.
Instructor, roundtable discussions, lectures

Small-group class discussions when we were able to really get into the issues. The guest lectures were also great for providing some specialized perspective, and I found the use of case studies helpful for tying the big picture issues to on-the-ground impacts and solutions.
the spread of topics covered in class
Allowing the discussions to be open-format and conducted by small student groups allowed for creative and innovative discussion formats which were both interesting and entertaining.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Sometimes the discussion sessions following the lecture could be fragmented as it is difficult to get so many people to provide opinions. In similar classes I have seen instructors divide the class in two groups for discussion, which helps discussions be more focused and productive, which could be tried in this class as well.

This class need to be better at timing lectures and discussion, and making sure we get out at the designated time. Too often, lecture ran long, leaving only 20 minutes or so for discussion, or the class went over time. But maybe I am the onlyone who had a problem with this because I had something scheduled right afterward that I was always running to.
Because it is such a specfiic subject, the material got to be a little repetative toward the end of the semester.
The selection of the guest speakers needs to be improved.

Though I enjoyed the discussion section of the course, I think it would be best to limit discussion to 45 minutes per class. That would leave more time for lecture and more time to cover more topics.I also would have liked to see a more detailed discussion of mitigation towards the end of the course. Maybe describe the relationship among GtC, ppm, and temperature increases. (Not sure how feasible this would be in an intro course)
student-led discussions
This is a great overview course.
The student-led discussions were not always thought-provoking and at times seemed like we could be using the time more effectively.
The reading reviews are not as interactive as they can be. Everyone just posts their opinion!
Deeper Knowledge and different weights on sections.
Some readings were outdated and didn't fit today's climate change debate
the student led discussion were sometimes a little weak. Perhaps some time could be dedicated, or perhaps give a reading about go to facilitate good discussion.
Readings should also include the view from the climate change skeptics! Otherwise we'll discuss just among "believers" without seeing the other point of views.
I would have found it easier if lecture was a bit more structured and if Rob spoke a little slower.
more instruction and supervision should be given to strengthen student presentations/discussions to faciliate a better intellectual exchange on critical issues in climate change.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both the instructor and the TAs were extremely approachable and available, and they went out of their way to make the class enjoyable and answer any questions/solve problems as quickly as possible.
The professor seemed pretty busy, but I found time to talk to him and he was extremely helpful in person. He's also very responsive to email, which I appreciated.
Professor Ballis and the TAs were always available for feedback and friendly to talk to.
The TAs and the professor were always available to help.

I didn't solicit much help from the TA's, but the instructor was very open and very willing to meet for office hours. Not only would professor Bailis help me with course material, but he would also take the time to help me explore research topics for my thesis project. I greatly appreciated this.
Instructor was helpful during office hours. I never interacted with the TAs, but I think they grade the commentaries.
Everyone was extremely helpful and responsive. I enjoyed the fact that the TAs and professor engaged in our class discussions.
Professor Bailis was very helpful in office hours.
Amazing. Everyone was really amazing. I never write this so please believe me.

Rob is available during his office hours and also during class breaks. I did not feel any inadequacy on that count. Both the TAs were pretty responsive as well. Julianne wrote excellent commentary on the reading reviews.
Discussion and final paper topic.
great
The feedback from both the Professor and TAs were great. In the case of the commentaries we do, it is great to have feedback from them so you do your best to present good ideas or opinion.
they all very helpful in providing guidance and assistance
Both the instructor and TAs provided very available, high-quality help.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I think this is a course all MEM students should take to fill any gaps in their understanding of climate change and current negotiations/measures being taken in this context.

My academic background is not in climate change, but I felt that it is such a big issue that I needed to know more about it. I still feel that way, and I think this class has greatly helped me. It relates a lot to my work in social ecology, because climate justice is a field I really would like to get into.
I think climate change is an important physical and political topic to be discussing in today's world especially with the risks associated with potential change.
I'm interested in the carbon cycle and this class gave me a good understanding of climate change.

I initally thought this course wouldn't fit into my overall energy cirriculum at FES. But after taking thiscourse, I think it is important to understand energy in the context of climate change adaptation and mitigation. This course is a great intro to climate change and explains many concepts that will be useful in pursuing any focus at FES.
Excellent intro to the multiple issues / sectors related to climate change

I come from a totally non-environmental/climate change background. I was looking for a course to give me an overview and bring me up the curve fast. This course did that and more. I am fairly conversant with the complexities of various aspects of climate change mitigation and adaptation.
Fair.
The course totally fits into my overall program in climate change and international governance.
climate change is a very relevant topic for all environmental managers. Because of this it is a great course to take.
I needed the class to fulfill the MESc requirement.
it provides a good overview on key issues in climate change field
I aim to have a position in energy or climate change consulting; therefore, this course was extremely relevant to my overall program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See answer to Question 15.
It related to my research interests and career goals.
Because it fits into my personal interests and because I wanted to have a deeper understanding of the climate change issues.
I though a class specifically on climate change would be really interesting since my knowledge on the issue is gained mostly from news articles.
Seemed like a good way to learn the basics about climate change.
I wanted to learn more about climate change.
See response for Q15
To have an overall knowledge on climate change issues.
I took this class in order to have the nitty-gritty of climate change.
wanted to learn about climate change

Because I am interested in Climate Change but have not taken any formal course on this. So I was looking for one class that can give the whole context in terms of scientific, economic, social and political issues around this topic.
MESc requirement
personal interests, important background for research
Having interned last summer at a renewable energy firm in a developing country, I was eager to reinforce and deepen my own learning of climate change.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, the course provided a good overview of climate change negotiations and measures as I was hoping for, and provided some interesting perspectives on the most current issues and events in this subject, which I appreciated.

Yes, I got a good understanding of the policy, governance, and science, which is hard to fit in one semester. It's a huge topic, so of course it did feel a little superficial at times, but I feel we were able to go in depth with a number of topics still.
Yes.
Not really
Yes.
yes
YES! I am finding that in my day to day life that I am much more informed and can discuss the issues involved in climate change in a more thoughtful and informed manner.
YES!
It definitely did.
Fair.
It did live up my expectation all in all.
yes
Yes
yes, it did.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: See answer to Question 17.
Yes
Yes.
Not really
yes.
yes
yes
If I did not I would have said so in the previous question. This question is redundant in my opinion.
Sure, I got out of it what I was expected.
yes
Yes
Yes
yes, it did.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I enjoyed the group dynamic when we led discussion, and I thought it was a good way to engage the students in at least one of the topics we covered, and presenting the readings in that way and getting students to participate in the discussion was a valuable experience.
It was challenging, but very helpful

I participated in a group as a facilitator for the discussion. It wasn't a group project. The advantages were that we didn't have to lead the discussion, by ourselves which can be intimidating and we had the opportunity to exchange views with our group, create a good presentation and ask more creative questions. I didn't find any disadvantages in working in the group.
it wasn't too extensive, but working on a group discussion with a couple classmates helped clarify the readings and build relationships with those classmates.
I enjoyed working with my group because it offered us an extra opportunity to engage on the topic in a more intimate setting.

I had to work with two other class mates to lead a class discussion. it was a good experience as we debated on the best way possible. There were differences of opinion which were amicably resolved. Unlike in the UNFCCC climate change negotiations!
I didn't get any disadvantage working in group since we understood each other easily.
we were both interested in the subject.
it fosters exchange of ideas on the specific topic we are presenting on, good experience. the flip side is we could make a even better session if people invest more time into it.
I enjoyed working with my group to lead our discussion section and experienced no disadvantages to this format of group work.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Definitely take this course if you want a broad, critical overview of all aspects of climate change science, negotiations or current measures/actions being taken.
This class is a lot of work, but it is worth it.
The course might seem heavy loaded because of the weekly commentaries, but it is not.
go to office hours if you need help
Start your weekly readings as early as possible.
Do all the readings. Read everything. It is the best way to really learn about this topic

Some people have mentioned that since the readings are a very important part of the course - why take the course at all and not just do independent reading. First, taking a credit class instills the discipline to do the readings. Also the weekly review requirement forces you to at least skim through the topics. My advice - start early on the reading commentary and if possible discuss it in a group. And do participate in the class discussions!
This is an intro course to have an overall knowledge on climate change
The need to be ready for readings, but a lot of readings as well as for the final paper.
it is agreat course but be prepared to put in the work.
You would enjoy the class if you are interested in the topic but make sure you read in advance to make the most of it.

The course will really help you refine your research ideas, so make sure you have at least a couple before taking it. Use the activities and assignments to get a head start on your research if you can--ie, call someone in the country you're working in for the interview assignment rather than just interviewing someone in New Haven.
avoid doing auditing becuase you would loose motivation to absorb all the good information in class.
Begin the readings early each week to leave enough time to compose a thoughtful reading response.
